header.title: An Approach To The Operation Of The Arbatel Of Magic

central_thesis: The essay proposes a simplified, practical method for operating with the Olympic Spirits as described in the "Isagoge" section of the "Arbatel of Magic", contextualizing the text within Western Esotericism and offering a direct, personal approach to its planetary magical system for contemporary practitioners.

structure_content.summary: Introduces the "Arbatel of Magic" as a 1575 Latin grimoire, noting its incomplete nature (only the "Isagoge" survived, promising eight further volumes on different magical traditions). It positions the "Arbatel" as a 'white magic' text and highlights the essay's focus on its third septenary concerning the Olympic Spirits and their evocation methods.

Details the seven chief Olympic Spirits (Aratron, Bethor, Phaleg, Och, Haggith, Ophiel, Phul), their corresponding planets (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sun, Venus, Mercury, Moon), their rule over 196 provinces, and their 490-year planetary cycles. It contextualizes the "Arbatel" by mentioning its potential influence on John Dee's work and its place within broader occult traditions.

Acknowledges the often confused and contradictory instructions in medieval grimoires. It presents the author's simplified and effective approach to working with the Olympic Spirits, meticulously listing the specific powers and abilities attributed to each spirit, ranging from health and wealth to alchemy and familiar spirits.

Outlines the practical ritual procedure for summoning and dismissing Olympic Spirits, including specific prayers, timing considerations based on planetary days and hours, and preparatory banishing rituals. It emphasizes the importance of the magician's belief and faith for the efficacy of the operations and warns against keeping spirits present for too long.
Provides an external reference to an online copy of the "Arbatel of Magic" at Joe and Candy Peterson's Twilit Grotto, noting that sigils and prayers may vary across different versions.

key_concepts.definition: A 1575 Latin grimoire, specifically its "Isagoge" (Fundamental Instructions) section, which is the only part that survived, promising eight additional volumes. It is considered by some to contain 'white magic' due to its less dangerous instructions compared to other grimoires.

The 'Fundamental Instructions' and only surviving part of the "Arbatel of Magic". It contains seven groups of seven aphorisms, combining Christian, Judaic, Pythagorean, and other esoteric lore, focusing on spiritual hierarchies, numbers, prayers, and secrets, with the third septenary discussing the Olympic Spirits.

Seven chief spirits (Aratron, Bethor, Phaleg, Och, Haggith, Ophiel, Phul), each corresponding to a planet or planetary sphere. They preside over the natural world, rule a certain number of provinces (196), and govern for 490-year cycles, each possessing distinct powers and attributes.

A specific period of time during a day that is traditionally associated with and governed by one of the seven classical planets. In Arbatel magic, operations with an Olympic Spirit are ideally timed during its corresponding planetary day and hour to enhance efficacy.
A magical symbol or emblem specific to an Olympic Spirit, which is to be drawn or written on paper as part of the invocation ritual, serving as a focal point or representation of the spirit.

A spirit entity that serves a magician. Several Olympic Spirits, such as Aratron, Bethor, Och, Haggith, and Phul, are described as being able to bestow or provide such familiar spirits to the practitioner.

A classification of magical practices perceived as benevolent, constructive, or aligned with positive spiritual goals, as opposed to 'Black Magic'. The "Arbatel" is categorized as 'white magic' by some occult scholars.

A category of historical magical texts, typically from the medieval or early modern periods, that provide instructions for invoking spirits, creating talismans, and performing other magical operations. The "Arbatel of Magic" is an example of a work within this tradition.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is a simplified, direct method for evoking the Olympic Spirits, primarily derived from the "Isagoge" of the "Arbatel of Magic". It emphasizes precise timing according to planetary days and hours, the creation of a personalized sigil, and the use of specific Christian-Kabbalistic prayers. The method integrates preparatory banishing rituals and suggests a meditative approach to interact with the spirits, aiming to gain instruction, assistance, or specific powers, while cautioning against prolonged contact.
tools: New paper for sigil and prayers
Sigils of the Olympic Spirits (as depicted or derived from traditional sources)
Knowledge of planetary days and hours for precise timing
Familiarity with standard banishing and opening rituals (e.g., LBRP, Middle Pillar)
rituals: Choose an Olympic Spirit based on the desired power (e.g., Aratron for alchemy, Och for health/wealth).
Determine the appropriate planetary day and hour that corresponds to the chosen spirit.
Perform preparatory banishing and opening rituals (e.g., Lesser Banishing Ritual of the Pentagram, Middle Pillar) to establish sacred space.
Write the spirit's sigil and the two prescribed prayers (summoning and dismissal) onto a new, clean piece of paper.
Read the first prayer aloud, facing a window if possible, and observe for subtle signs of the spirit's manifestation (e.g., an animal appearing, a sudden sound).
Enter a meditative state, using the first prayer as an opening to focus on the spirit's particular powers, aiming for direct contact and potential conversation.
Limit the spirit's presence to no more than one hour to avoid the spirit becoming 'familiarly addicted'.
Read the second prayer (dismissal) once the operation is complete and the 'charge delivered'.
Store the paper containing the sigil and prayers in a safe place, or carry it as a talisman.

relevant_quotes.text: The "Arbatel of Magic" appeared at Basle, Switzerland in 1575 in Latin and is one of the lesser known works of the 'grimoire' tradition. Waite writes that it has the quality of true transcendental literature, being free from 'dangerous instruction which makes for open Black Magic.' While it may be going a little to far to praise it as having transcendental quality, it can be considered more aligned with 'white magic' (whatever that may be) than most other books of the grimoire tradition.

It is unfortunate that only one part of the book has survived or was ever written, being called the Isagoge, or Fundamental Instructions. The work promised a further eight volumes, concerning themselves with "Microcosmical Magic", "Olympic Magic", "Hesiodiacal and Homerical Magic", "Sibylline Magic", "Pythagorical Magic", "The Magic of Appolonius", "Hermetical Magic" and "Prophetical Magic".

The Olympic Spirits are the spirits which, under God, preside over the natural world. There are seven chief spirits, each corresponding to a planet (or planetary sphere), and having under them a certain number of provinces being 196 in number (although the book wrongly states 186).
Therefore, the current ruler is Ophiel.

"Omnipotent and eternal God, who hast ordained the whole creation for thy praise and thy glory, as also for the salvation of man, I beseech Thee to send Thy Spirit (name), of the (order - solar etc.) order, that he may instruct me concerning those things about which I design to ask him. Nevertheless, not my will be done, but thine, through Jesus Christ, thy only begotten Son, Who is our Lord. Amen."

"Forasmuch as thou camest in peace and quietly, having also answered unto my petitions, I give thanks unto God, in Whose Name thou camest. Now thou mayst depart in peace unto thy orders; but return unto me again, when I shall call thee by thy name, or by thy order, or by thy office, which is granted from the Creator. Amen."
However, the Arbatel warns that you should not keep the spirit more than one hour or it may become 'familiarly addicted to thee'.

critical_analysis.relevance: This essay is highly relevant for both practitioners and scholars of grimoire traditions, particularly those interested in the "Arbatel of Magic". It provides a clear, accessible interpretation of a historically significant text often obscured by complex or contradictory instructions. By simplifying the operative steps and offering a contextual overview of the Olympic Spirits, it effectively bridges the gap between historical magical theory and contemporary practice. Its discussion of the "Arbatel"'s relation to figures like John Dee and its 'white magic' classification adds significant academic value, contributing to a nuanced understanding of its place within Western Esotericism. The mention of current planetary rulers makes it immediately actionable for modern practitioners.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes occult practitioners seeking to engage with traditional grimoire magic, particularly the "Arbatel"; students and scholars of Western Esotericism and magic history; and individuals interested in planetary magic and the Olympic Spirits who may find the original texts challenging. It is especially useful for those looking for a simplified, yet respectful and effective, approach to traditional spirit evocation, offering a practical pathway into the system.
